Large Variety of Caps

At the first meeting of the 'Varsity debating teams, which was held
at twelve o'clock last Friday, preparations for the contests with Virginia and North Carolina, to take
place on the 24th of April, were
begun.
The Hopkins teams have decided
to defend the negative of the colonial expansion question at North
Carolina, and the affirmative at
Virginia, this course affording, in
the opinion of the majority of the
Debating Council, the greatest possible advantage to the speakers who
will represent the University.
The Councils of the two other institutions having agreed that Mr.
Albert L. Hammond, a graduate
student at Hopkins and instructor
in Public Speaking I, is eligible to
participate in the debates, it has
been decided to send him to Virginia, where, together with C.
Sewell Weech, he will oppose the
representatives of North Carolina.
Avra M. Warren and Thomas J.
Tingley will go to Chapel Hill to
meet the Virginia debaters.
The two Hopkins teams will cooperate in their work of preparation, and thus each man will be
given a thorough knowledge of
both sides of the question. This
system has always worked excellently in the past, and is expected
to result in a double victory for the
local representatives this season.
The team advisers, who will be appointed later, will also assist in the
preparation of the debate, and will
be rewarded with "H's" if the Hopkins men are victorious.

Delinquents Cannot Use Summer School.

Delinquent students at Dartmouth, according to an official announcement, will not hereafter be
permitted to make up their deficiencies by attendance at the Dartmouth summer schools. In past
years 75 per cent, of the students
attending the summer schools had
failed in one or more courses during the previous college term.

MISSIONARY CONFERENCE MEETS

MUSICIANS' PROSPECTS BRIGHT

Meetings Held on Saturday and Sunday
at Goucher College Hopkins Men
Make Important Addresses.

Singers and Instrumentalists Achieving
Further Success —Several Additions
Made to Schedule Good Trips.

The Intercollegiate AlissionarY
Conference held meetings on Saturday and Sunday at Catherine
Hooper Hall, of Goucher College.
A large number of Hopkins men
interested in missions were present.
At the morning meeting on Saturday Miss Mary George White
was leader and Mr. A. E. Chenoweth, of New York, made the address. Dr. Charles R. Watson, of
Philadelphia, spoke at the afternoon
meeting, which was led by Mr. A.
E. Lindley.
At the evening meeting on Saturday, addresses were made by three
Hopkins students, whose familiarity
with conditions in foreign missionary fields renders them peculiarly
capable to deal comprehensively
with the subjects at hand. Messrs.
Youel B. Mirza, S. F. Woo and
H. C. Chen spoke, outlining the
work that Christianity is doing in
the foreign fields, and pointing out
the special needs of each of the
fields for the future.
Mr. Walter D. Sutton, the secretary of the University Young
Men's Christian Association, is the
president of the Baltimore organization of student volunteers. This
organization is a band of Baltimore
college students who are preparing
themselves to do work in foreign
fields.
Meetings of the Conference were
held at three o'clock Sunday afternoon and at eight o'clock Sunday
night, at which addresses were
made by Miss H. E. Haggard, of
Boston, who is a student volunteer,
and the travelling secretary of the
organization, and Dr. Adrian S.
Taylor, who has been doing efficient
medical missionary work in China
for the past seven years.
The delegates, with the colleges
they represent, are:
Misses Alma Burnworth, Hilda
Ostram, J. T. Fenley, Guy Leister,
J. W. Engle, H. C. Elderdice and
T. L. Hooper, Western Maryland
College.
I. D. Love and J. E. Smith,

Hemmelbaugh, Hood College; Bill
Wighton, Jr., and I. B. Valton, St.
John's College; Misses Alice Rockwell, Matilda Robinson, Miriam
Uhler and Clara Wagner, Goucher
College; H. M. Wagner, Misses
Hildegrade Germann and Katharine Pardee, Johns Hopkins University.

BALTIMORE, MD., MAR. 1, 1915.
The Alumni Advisers.

With the system of alumni advisership to the athletic teams has
- come the beginning of a new era in
the development of athletics at
Johns Hopkins. Under the new
type of supervision the various athletic activities at the University
have taken on a new life. The
undergraduates are showing much
more interest on account of the fact
that the alumni are taking time and
trouble to help them in their work,
and a new spirit of enthusiasm has
grown up among the alumni, which
is being clearly shown by the fact
that they are paying close attention
to the welfare of the younger men's
interests. It is the beginning of a
period in which the true value of
good athletic teams will be brought
out most forcibly by the success
which must follow when two strong
factors such as the students and the
'alumni, are united with a common
interest — the development of a
stronger and better-supervised system of athletics at Johns Hopkins.
The beginning of this new interest which the alumni have shown
in the management of undergraduate activities could not have been
indicated in a more pointed manner
than it was in the speech of Mr.
Gustav Stewart which was printed
in the preceding issue of THE
NEWS-LETTER. In this speech Mr.

THE RELAY TEAM VICTORIOUS

Rain Insurance at Allegheny.

there happens to be rain about
4 o'clock on the afternoon of next
June 21, 22 and 23 on the campus
of Allegheny College at Meadville,
Pa., a check for $5,000 will change
hands as a result. But if the sun
goes down over the hill in a guaranteed saffron glow it will be quite
different. For in that case the historical pageant which is to mark the
one hundredth anniversary of the
founding of the college will be assured the natural lighting effects
which are absolutely necessary for
its production. The committee in
charge has insured the climatic conditions for the days of the pageant
with Lloyd's, who will distribute the
$5,000 insurance among the various
insurance companies. The guarantee fund subscribed by fifty alumni
will be partly applied to cover the
cost of the premiums.

Sutton Captures a First.

Another first was captured by
Paul Sutton, who, although he had
already taken third in the 600-yard
novice race, was able to break the
tape in the open 44o-yard dash a
little later, in 57 2-5. His handicap was ten yards. Captain Connolly made a good showing with a
total of five points—a second and
two third places—in spite of large
and discouraging handicaps against
him. He took second in the S. A.
I. high jump, third in the S. A. I.
shot-put, and third in the open high
jump.
Binford and Thompson each got
second place in their heats of the
50-yard dash, but the finals proved
too fast for them.
This meet ends the indoor work,
and the men will now be given a
month's rest before getting into
shape for the hard outdoor schedule, which opens with a dual meet
with Navy on April 17, and the
Pennsylvania Relay Carnival a week
later.

HULLABALOO TO GO TO PRESS
WITHIN THE NEXT FEW WEEKS

BALTIMORE IS A LEADER IN
CIVIC WORK,SAYS MR. ZUEBLIN

With but little more than two
weeks left before the 1915 Hullabaloo goes to press the Board is beginning to show signs of great activity. Instead of giving the printers all of the material at a late
date and making them rush the
work through, the Board is preparing to have copy in as soon as possible.
Although it has been emphasized
several times in THE NEWS-LETTER
the business manager wishes to
make it perfectly clear that only
a limited number of the 1915 Hullabaloo will be printed. Those
students who do not make arrangements for- ordering the book very
soon will be unable to get a Hullabaloo when they are distributed.
The 1915 Board is thus establishing
a precedent from which coming
classes will derive great benefit.
Mr. Warren, of the art department, announces that he wants cartoons depicting University life,
especially classroom occurrences.
There are still some individual and
group pictures f-at 1-ave not been
taken. Pictures that are taken late
are not likely to make as good cuts
as those which are ready on time.
The Board takes pleasure in announcing the election of Mr. Wilmer Brinton to the Board of Editors. Mr. Brinton was chosen to
fill a vacancy caused by the resig7
nation of one of the editors.

"The New Civic Spirit- was the
subject of an address delivered by
Charles Zueblin last • Wednesday
evening in McCoy Hall under the
auspices of the Women's Civic
League and the City Club.
Mr. Zueblin, who was formerly..
professor of sociology at the University of Chicago, now devotes his
whole time to the preaching of civics. He is a publicist of some note
and the author of a number of
books. We may, therefore, believe
him when he says Baltimore has
much to be proud of, for he speaks
with authority.
There are many things for city
betterment and general welfare in
which Baltimore has stood first.
Mr. Zueblin enumerated a number
of the activities which mark Baltimore's leadership in civic development. The Municipal Art Society
was the first organization of its
kind; the sewerage system is the
last word in the scientific disposal of
sewage; the parks and public baths
are among the best.
All over the country, he said, the
new civic spirit has been felt.
Twenty years ago, if a young man
desired to serve the people there
were but three avenues open—the
church, the schools and charity.
Politics at that time was closed to
him. But the day will come, Mr.
Zueblin predicted, when men will
-go into public office with the same
spirit of consecration they now go

Engineers to Meet Friday.

The regular monthly meeting of
the Engineering Society will be
held at Homewood next Friday
night. The speakers will be Messrs.
Hutton and Evitt, both of whom
will talk on matters of pertinent
interest to the engineering students.

Large Variety of Caps

At the first meeting of the 'Varsity debating teams, which was held
at twelve o'clock last Friday, preparations for the contests with Virginia and North Carolina, to take
place on the 24th of April, were
begun.
The Hopkins teams have decided
to defend the negative of the colonial expansion question at North
Carolina, and the affirmative at
Virginia, this course affording, in
the opinion of the majority of the
Debating Council, the greatest possible advantage to the speakers who
will represent the University.
The Councils of the two other institutions having agreed that Mr.
Albert L. Hammond, a graduate
student at Hopkins and instructor
in Public Speaking I, is eligible to
participate in the debates, it has
been decided to send him to Virginia, where, together with C.
Sewell Weech, he will oppose the
representatives of North Carolina.
Avra M. Warren and Thomas J.
Tingley will go to Chapel Hill to
meet the Virginia debaters.
The two Hopkins teams will cooperate in their work of preparation, and thus each man will be
given a thorough knowledge of
both sides of the question. This
system has always worked excellently in the past, and is expected
to result in a double victory for the
local representatives this season.
The team advisers, who will be appointed later, will also assist in the
preparation of the debate, and will
be rewarded with "H's" if the Hopkins men are victorious.

MISSIONARY CONFERENCE MEETS

MUSICIANS' PROSPECTS BRIGHT

Meetings Held on Saturday and Sunday
at Goucher College Hopkins Men
Make Important Addresses.

Singers and Instrumentalists Achieving
Further Success —Several Additions
Made to Schedule Good Trips.

The Intercollegiate AlissionarY
Conference held meetings on Saturday and Sunday at Catherine
Hooper Hall, of Goucher College.
A large number of Hopkins men
interested in missions were present.
At the morning meeting on Saturday Miss Mary George White
was leader and Mr. A. E. Chenoweth, of New York, made the address. Dr. Charles R. Watson, of
Philadelphia, spoke at the afternoon
meeting, which was led by Mr. A.
E. Lindley.
At the evening meeting on Saturday, addresses were made by three
Hopkins students, whose familiarity
with conditions in foreign missionary fields renders them peculiarly
capable to deal comprehensively
with the subjects at hand. Messrs.
Youel B. Mirza, S. F. Woo and
H. C. Chen spoke, outlining the
work that Christianity is doing in
the foreign fields, and pointing out
the special needs of each of the
fields for the future.
Mr. Walter D. Sutton, the secretary of the University Young
Men's Christian Association, is the
president of the Baltimore organization of student volunteers. This
organization is a band of Baltimore
college students who are preparing
themselves to do work in foreign
fields.
Meetings of the Conference were
held at three o'clock Sunday afternoon and at eight o'clock Sunday
night, at which addresses were
made by Miss H. E. Haggard, of
Boston, who is a student volunteer,
and the travelling secretary of the
organization, and Dr. Adrian S.
Taylor, who has been doing efficient
medical missionary work in China
for the past seven years.

BALTIMORE, MD., MAR. 1, 1915.
The Alumni Advisers.

With the system of alumni advisership to the athletic teams has
- come the beginning of a new era in
the development of athletics at
Johns Hopkins. Under the new
type of supervision the various athletic activities at the University
have taken on a new life. The
undergraduates are showing much
more interest on account of the fact
that the alumni are taking time and
trouble to help them in their work,
and a new spirit of enthusiasm has
grown up among the alumni, which
is being clearly shown by the fact
that they are paying close attention
to the welfare of the younger men's
interests. It is the beginning of a
period in which the true value of
good athletic teams will be brought
out most forcibly by the success
which must follow when two strong
factors such as the students and the
'alumni, are united with a common
interest — the development of a
stronger and better-supervised system of athletics at Johns Hopkins.
The beginning of this new interest which the alumni have shown
in the management of undergraduate activities could not have been
indicated in a more pointed manner
than it was in the speech of Mr.
Gustav Stewart which was printed
in the preceding issue of THE
NEWS-LETTER. In this speech Mr.
Stewart has sounded the keynote
of the whole affair—more attention
on the part of the alumni to the
interests of the University, not least
among which is athletics.
Certainly we are fortunate in
having the interest of such men as
are now on the various committees.

Rain Insurance at Allegheny.

there happens to be rain about
4 o'clock on the afternoon of next
June 21, 22 and 23 on the campus
of Allegheny College at Meadville,
Pa., a check for $5,000 will change
hands as a result. But if the sun
goes down over the hill in a guaranteed saffron glow it will be quite
different. For in that case the historical pageant which is to mark the
one hundredth anniversary of the
founding of the college will be assured the natural lighting effects
which are absolutely necessary for
its production. The committee in
charge has insured the climatic conditions for the days of the pageant
with Lloyd's, who will distribute the
$5,000 insurance among the various
insurance companies. The guarantee fund subscribed by fifty alumni
will be partly applied to cover the
cost of the premiums.

Sutton Captures a First.

Another first was captured by
Paul Sutton, who, although he had
already taken third in the 600-yard
novice race, was able to break the
tape in the open 44o-yard dash a
little later, in 57 2-5. His handicap was ten yards. Captain Connolly made a good showing with a
total of five points—a second and
two third places—in spite of large
and discouraging handicaps against
him. He took second in the S. A.
I. high jump, third in the S. A. I.
shot-put, and third in the open high
jump.
Binford and Thompson each got
second place in their heats of the
50-yard dash, but the finals proved
too fast for them.
This meet ends the indoor work,
and the men will now be given a
month's rest before getting into
shape for the hard outdoor schedule, which opens with a dual meet
with Navy on April 17, and the
Pennsylvania Relay Carnival a week
later.

THE JOHNS HOPKINS NEWS-LETTER, MARCH

6
HULLABALOO TO GO TO PRESS
WITHIN THE NEXT FEW WEEKS

BALTIMORE IS A LEADER IN
CIVIC WORK,SAYS MR. ZUEBLIN

With but little more than two
weeks left before the 1915 Hullabaloo goes to press the Board is beginning to show signs of great activity. Instead of giving the printers all of the material at a late
date and making them rush the
work through, the Board is preparing to have copy in as soon as possible.
Although it has been emphasized
several times in THE NEWS-LETTER
the business manager wishes to
make it perfectly clear that only
a limited number of the 1915 Hullabaloo will be printed. Those
students who do not make arrangements for- ordering the book very
soon will be unable to get a Hullabaloo when they are distributed.
The 1915 Board is thus establishing
a precedent from which coming
classes will derive great benefit.
Mr. Warren, of the art department, announces that he wants cartoons depicting University life,
especially classroom occurrences.
There are still some individual and
group pictures f-at 1-ave not been
taken. Pictures that are taken late
are not likely to make as good cuts
as those which are ready on time.
The Board takes pleasure in announcing the election of Mr. Wilmer Brinton to the Board of Editors. Mr. Brinton was chosen to
fill a vacancy caused by the resig7
nation of one of the editors.

"The New Civic Spirit- was the
subject of an address delivered by
Charles Zueblin last • Wednesday
evening in McCoy Hall under the
auspices of the Women's Civic
League and the City Club.
Mr. Zueblin, who was formerly..
professor of sociology at the University of Chicago, now devotes his
whole time to the preaching of civics. He is a publicist of some note
and the author of a number of
books. We may, therefore, believe
him when he says Baltimore has
much to be proud of, for he speaks
with authority.
There are many things for city
betterment and general welfare in
which Baltimore has stood first.
Mr. Zueblin enumerated a number
of the activities which mark Baltimore's leadership in civic development. The Municipal Art Society
was the first organization of its
kind; the sewerage system is the
last word in the scientific disposal of
sewage; the parks and public baths
are among the best.
All over the country, he said, the
new civic spirit has been felt.
Twenty years ago, if a young man
desired to serve the people there
were but three avenues open—the
church, the schools and charity.
Politics at that time was closed to
him. But the day will come, Mr.
Zueblin predicted, when men will
-go into public office with the same
spirit of consecration they now go

Engineers to Meet Friday.

The regular monthly meeting of
the Engineering Society will be
held at Homewood next Friday
night. The speakers will be Messrs.
Hutton and Evitt, both of whom
will talk on matters of pertinent
interest to the engineering students.
The proposition of forming a collegiate branch of the American Society of Mechanical Engineers will
also be taken up. All members of
the University are invited to attend
the meeting.

preparation for Business and Business Administration.
